Somebody might ask you "When were you born?".

We say "I was born..." and notice we are using

We're not saying "I am born", we are saying,

So, the next thing I want to talk about are

A false friend is when you have a word in
your language and a similar looking word in

English and you think they mean the same thing
because they look similar but they really
have different meanings.
We call these "false friends".

English has many false friends with languages
like French, Spanish, Portuguese, Italian,

German, so any languages that share a similar
history with English often have friends that
are false.
So, I'm going to give you an example of this.
Anniversary.

This word exists in many different languages,
or similar words to anniversary, they look
very similar, but they have different meanings.
In English, an anniversary is not a birthday.

We use the word anniversary when we're talking
about a special date that happens once a year
where we remember something.
So, for example, we might have a wedding anniversary.

We might have the anniversary of an important
event in our life, but we do not use anniversary
when we are talking about birthdays, okay?
So these do not equal the same thing.
